title: 104_hr4200
content: The new section 198 allows for the expensing of environmental remediation costs under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A taxpayer can elect to treat qualified environmental remediation expenditures as expenses not chargeable to capital account, allowing for a deduction in the year paid or incurred. These expenditures are for abatement or control of hazardous substances at a contaminated site. Qualified environmental remediation expenditures are expenses for abatement or control of hazardous substances at a contaminated site. A qualified contaminated site is an area held by the taxpayer for business or income production purposes. Qualified environmental remediation expenditures are expenses for abatement or control of hazardous substances at a contaminated site held by the taxpayer for business purposes. To be considered a qualified contaminated site, the taxpayer must receive a statement from the state environmental agency confirming that the area meets specific requirements. The appropriate agency of a State designated by the EPA must provide this statement. The term 'hazardous substance' for this section includes substances defined under various environmental acts, such as the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act of 1986, asbestos, and radon. The term 'hazardous substance' includes substances like asbestos, radon, lead paint, and petroleum products. Excluded substances are those for which removal or remedial action is not permitted under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. Deductions for qualified environmental remediation expenditures are recaptured as ordinary income on sale. The text discusses the treatment of property as section 1245 property for deduction purposes and the coordination with other provisions. The Secretary is authorized to prescribe regulations for this section. The text discusses the expensing of environmental remediation costs, with amendments applying to expenditures paid or incurred after the enactment date of the Act.
